channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Hundreds of thousands in L.A. County may have the coronavirus, study finds
item.dc:creator: Melanie Mason
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of L.A. County residents may have been infected with the coronavirus by early April, outpacing total of known cases, report says.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of thousands of L.A. County residents may have been infected with the coronavirus by early April, outpacing total of known cases, report says.

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 2020: Healthcare workers tend to a driver in line at a drive-through Coronavirus (COVID-19) testing site at the Westminster Mall in Westminster, CA, Wednesday, April 8, 2020. The site is run by Elevated Health and is doing nasal testing for $125 and antibody testing for $75. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Street repairs, tree trimming, graffiti removal face cuts under Garcetti budget plan
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith, David Zahniser, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti's budget would impose cuts across agencies as the city copes with the coronavirus. He seeks to furlough 15,000 workers.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti's budget would impose cuts across agencies as the city copes with the coronavirus. He seeks to furlough 15,000 workers.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- SUNDAY, APRIL 19, 2020: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti tears up as he gives his annual 'State of the City' speech at City Hall in Los Angeles, Calif., on April 19, 2020. (MANDATORY CREDIT: Pool photo by Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here's how to get tested for the coronavirus in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: More testing and contact tracing are key to assessing the pandemic's scope and taking steps toward lifting stay-at-home orders, health officials say.
item.content:encoded: More testing and contact tracing are key to assessing the pandemic's scope and taking steps toward lifting stay-at-home orders, health officials say.

media:content.media:description: BELL-CA-APRIL 20, 2020: A symptomatic person drops a specimen at a new COVID-19 mobile testing site in Bell on Wednesday, April 20, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Painful closures lie ahead for L.A. galleries. How 35 are bracing for the worst
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: An L.A. Times survey of Los Angeles art galleries on a slimmed-down post-pandemic future. Some are banding together to weather the storm.
item.content:encoded: An L.A. Times survey of Los Angeles art galleries on a slimmed-down post-pandemic future. Some are banding together to weather the storm.

media:content.media:description: An installation view of the group show "All of Them Witches" at Jeffrey Deitch in Hollywood. The exhibition, a group show organized by painter Laurie Simmons and independent curator Dan Nadel, closed prematurely due to the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Newsom's secretive $1-billion mask deal with Chinese automaker sparks bipartisan concerns
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Concerns have emerged that Newsom has committed $990 million — without briefing lawmakers — on masks to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Concerns have emerged that Newsom has committed $990 million — without briefing lawmakers — on masks to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif., Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Newsom said he won't loosen the state's mandatory stay-at-home order until hospitalizations, particularly those in intensive care units, "flatten and start to decline."(AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Over 100 coronavirus deaths in 2 days in L.A. County; Ventura County relaxes restrictions
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, David Zahniser, Dakota Smith, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: As deaths from COVID-19 continue to mount in Los Angeles County, neighboring Ventura County eases some of its coronavirus restrictions.
item.content:encoded: As deaths from COVID-19 continue to mount in Los Angeles County, neighboring Ventura County eases some of its coronavirus restrictions.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 18: A man walks by a mural on La Brea Ave by artist Thierry Guetta, aka Mr. Brainwash, has the bold message of "Stay Home, Life is Beautiful," made during the coronavirus pandemic, photographed Saturday, April 18, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. Guetta is known for "Life is Beautiful" being used in his pop-art, including in a 2019 campaign for the city of Beverly Hills. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Machine that could decontaminate 20,000 masks daily has arrived in Burbank, company says
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Battelle says its cleaning unit has arrived at the Burbank airport. It could help alleviate hospital shortages of personal protective equipment.
item.content:encoded: Battelle says its cleaning unit has arrived at the Burbank airport. It could help alleviate hospital shortages of personal protective equipment.

media:content.media:description: Larry Difabrizio and Camille Davis RN, Mount Sinai, ER in their personal protection equipment (PPE). LA Times photos by Charles Powell, MD
media:content.media:credit: Charles Powell, MD/Charles Powell, MD/Charles Powell, MD

item.title: 15 deaths in the airline industry in 9 days linked to coronavirus. Why are planes still flying?
item.dc:creator: Kiera Feldman
item.description: Flights are nearly empty and airlines have cut service drastically, but the coronavirus is still ravaging the workforce.
item.content:encoded: Flights are nearly empty and airlines have cut service drastically, but the coronavirus is still ravaging the workforce.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MARCH 23: During the coroniavirus empdemic it's quiet night at LAX in Los Angeles, Calif. on Monday, March 23, 2020. Major U.S. airlines are drafting plans for a potential voluntary shutdown of virtually all passenger flights across the U.S., according to industry and federal officials. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protesters demand California stay-at-home rules end. Here is how that could happen
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa, Patrick McGreevy, Alex Wigglesworth, Teri Figueroa
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom says he will not be swayed by public protests in deciding when to reopen the state amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom says he will not be swayed by public protests in deciding when to reopen the state amid the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - APRIL 17: A big number of Trump supporters rally on Main Street against business closure due to COVID-19 pandemic. Huntington Beach, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here is the latest tally of coronavirus cases in each L.A. County community
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Officials reported 24 deaths related to COVID-19 and 334 cases of the coronavirus Sunday.
item.content:encoded: Officials reported 24 deaths related to COVID-19 and 334 cases of the coronavirus Sunday.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA-CA-APRIL 19, 2020: Passers-by stop to enjoy classical music played by Beong-Soo Kim and his wife Bonnie Wongtrakool at their home in Pasadena on Sunday, April 19, 2020. The couple began playing classical music on their front porch when Los Angeles issued it's safer-at-home order. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: It's natural to long for an end to the coronavirus quarantine. But we should remember what it has shown us
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: Our current crisis is not just a pandemic, but also a human-made disaster of all the things we've grown accustomed to overlooking.
item.content:encoded: Our current crisis is not just a pandemic, but also a human-made disaster of all the things we've grown accustomed to overlooking.

item.title: L.A. school district confronts $200 million in coronavirus costs and a grim budget future
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: The Los Angeles school district racks up $200 million in emergency coronavirus costs, from meal programs to computers, and the budget outlook is uncertain at best.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles school district racks up $200 million in emergency coronavirus costs, from meal programs to computers, and the budget outlook is uncertain at best.

media:content.media:description: SUN VALLEY, CA - APRIL 17: Parents wait in line to get meal packages provided by LAUSD at a grab-and-go food center established on Friday morning at Byrd Middle School. LAUSD is providing meals to students in the wake of school closures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Sun Valley, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: London Breed, a mayor who scolds and empathizes, is San Francisco's face of the coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco Mayor London Breed has been criticized for some of her decisions. But her early action on the coronavirus pandemic is also earning her praise.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco Mayor London Breed has been criticized for some of her decisions. But her early action on the coronavirus pandemic is also earning her praise.

media:content.media:description: San Francisco Mayor London Breed announces the first confirmed cases of novel coronavirus in the city alongside public health and city officials during a news conference at City Hall in San Francisco, Thursday, March 5, 2020.

item.title: From quiet acceptance to 'crippling fear,' medical workers confront their own mortality
item.dc:creator: Kiera Feldman, Anita Chabria, Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: With Californians anxious for looser restrictions, medical workers feel caught in a state of perpetual danger, with no end in sight. Some are preparing their wills.
item.content:encoded: With Californians anxious for looser restrictions, medical workers feel caught in a state of perpetual danger, with no end in sight. Some are preparing their wills.

media:content.media:description: THOUSAND OAKS, CA - APRIL 15: Kim Ballon a Ventura County In Home Support Services (IHSS) care provider attends to Marjorie Williams, 84, at her Thousand Oaks home as California does little to track safety of health care workers during the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic. Ballon is worried about a lack of protective gear though she regularly cares for elderly clients, helping them bathe and multiple tasks. (keep as a silhouette) Thousand Oaks on Wednesday, April 15, 2020 in Thousand Oaks, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite probation's support, L.A. County blocks at-risk offender's releases amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Despite a statewide push to reduce adult jail populations to prevent spread of the coronavirus, L.A. County kids and young people face hurdles when they seek release
item.content:encoded: Despite a statewide push to reduce adult jail populations to prevent spread of the coronavirus, L.A. County kids and young people face hurdles when they seek release

media:content.media:description: PACOIMA, CA- APRIL 17, 2020: Dorian Martinez wants her 17 year old son released from a juvenile detention camp early since he suffers from asthma and bronchitis, but so far a judge has denied the request during the coronavirus pandemic on April 17, 2020 in Pacoima, California. He has already served almost 6 months of his 7 month sentence for violating his probation.***Attention Prepress: keep the shadows dark. This is how the photo was originally shot.** (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Newsom is helping immigrants amid coronavirus pandemic. There's nothing Trump can do about it
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Gov. Newsom authorized payments to immigrant workers as reconciliation for their snub by the president and Republican U.S. Senate.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom authorized payments to immigrant workers as reconciliation for their snub by the president and Republican U.S. Senate.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom listens to a reporters question concerning his announcement that California schools will likely remain closed for the rest of the school year, but provide off-site education due to the coronavirus, during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. in Rancho Cordova, Calif., Wednesday, April 1, 2020. The state is not mandating that schools remain closed through the summer break but offering guidance and recommendations on distance learning for schools. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, POOL)

item.title: This Marin County town offering coronavirus testing to every resident
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: The Bay Area town of Bolinas is among the first communities in the world to attempt to test all of its residents for the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: The Bay Area town of Bolinas is among the first communities in the world to attempt to test all of its residents for the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: A kayaker paddles out as a fisherman returns in Bolinas Bay.

item.title: Coronavirus stay-at-home order saves state taxpayers $1 billion after car crashes cut by 60%
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: California's stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus reduced vehicle collisions on roadways by roughly half, saving taxpayers an estimated $1 billion.
item.content:encoded: California's stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus reduced vehicle collisions on roadways by roughly half, saving taxpayers an estimated $1 billion.

media:content.media:description: Police agencies throughout Los Angeles County have been taking part in a nationwide effort to curb driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Above, traffic on the southbound Harbor Freeway in Los Angeles.

item.title: Garcetti: L.A. is 'under attack' and will need to furlough thousands of city workers

item.content:encoded: In a remarkable State of the City address, Mayor Eric Garcetti said L.A. is "under attack" from the coronavirus, with its daily life "unrecognizable." He said major cuts would be needed.

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 24 deaths related to COVID-19 and 334 cases of the coronavirus Sunday, marking its lowest single-day increase in fatalities in over a week.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 18: Coronavirus pandemic has changed shoppers as well as vendors at Santa Monica Farmers Market. Everyone is observing social distancing, wearing masks, gloves and stand in long lines to get get in. Santa Monica, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County eases parts of its coronavirus stay-at-home order

item.description: Ventura County modified its coronavirus stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some gatherings to take place.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County modified its coronavirus stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some gatherings to take place.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - APRIL 15: John Dodson, 69, takes his 3 and a half mile walk to the Ventura Pier in the City of Ventura Wednesday morning as the sunshine and warm temperatures brought people to the beach despite warnings about the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic. Ventura on Wednesday, April 15, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tourist-dependent Solvang struggles through coronavirus stay-home orders in California
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter, Photography by Genaro Molina
item.description: Solvang, Calif., with its windmills and half-timbered architecture, draws more than 1½ million visitors a year. It's a virtual ghost town now.
item.content:encoded: Solvang, Calif., with its windmills and half-timbered architecture, draws more than 1½ million visitors a year. It's a virtual ghost town now.

media:content.media:description: SOLVANG, CA - APRIL 16, 2020 - - Locals Alicja Clarke, right, and Jusyna Zimkowski, enjoy a conversation while reflected in a nearby storefront window along with the iconic windmill on Alisal Road in Solvang, California on April 16, 2020. Clark has not been working since The Copenhagen House had to close due to the coronavirus pandemic. Solvang is a tiny town of 5,300 people nestled in the Santa Ynez Valley wine country, about a half-hour north of Santa Barbara. Tourists - mainly those who make the short drive from Los Angeles and Orange counties -- are the engine of an economy than generates nearly $200 million in economic activity a year. And without it hundreds in Solvang and the surrounding bedroom communities have lost their jobs while the city is losing $500,000 in tax revenue a month. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protesters fed up with coronavirus stay-home orders rally in downtown San Diego
item.dc:creator: Andrea Lopez-Villafana, Teri Figueroa
item.description: At least 200 protesters in San Diego demanded businesses, parks and schools reopen in rally that ignored social distancing practices.
item.content:encoded: At least 200 protesters in San Diego demanded businesses, parks and schools reopen in rally that ignored social distancing practices.

media:content.media:description: Angela Royal was among the estimated 200 supporters calling to reopen California. The group held their rally on the corner at State Street and Broadway on Saturday.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Earthquake: 3.3 quake near Carpinteria
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported at 1:34 a.m. Sunday six miles from Carpinteria, Calif.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported at 1:34 a.m. Sunday six miles from Carpinteria, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported at 1:34 a.m. 4/19/2020 six miles from Carpinteria, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: California lessons from the 1918 pandemic: San Francisco dithered; Los Angeles acted and saved lives
item.dc:creator: James Rainey, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: San Francisco went mask crazy. Los Angeles shut down early and stayed closed longer, but not long enough. Some lessons from the 1918 Spanish flu.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco went mask crazy. Los Angeles shut down early and stayed closed longer, but not long enough. Some lessons from the 1918 Spanish flu.

media:content.media:description: A handout picture provided by the California State Library shows people waiting in line to get flu masks on Montgomery Street in San Francisco, California, in 1918. Unlike Los Angeles, San Francisco stressed mask wearing, but not social distancing during the Spanish flu pandemic.

item.title: Advocates say hundreds of immigrants detained in California are on hunger strike. ICE says only two
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Detainees say they are protesting conditions inside facilities that leave them at risk for contracting the novel coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Detainees say they are protesting conditions inside facilities that leave them at risk for contracting the novel coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: Hunger strikers at Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield captured by drone during a sit-in protest on April 10.
media:content.media:credit: Courtesy of the California Committee for Immigrant Liberation

item.title: This federal judge is risking his life to save homeless people from the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: At 76, Judge David Carter knows he shouldn't be on skid row exposing himself to the coronavirus. But he wants more for L.A.'s homeless people.
item.content:encoded: At 76, Judge David Carter knows he shouldn't be on skid row exposing himself to the coronavirus. But he wants more for L.A.'s homeless people.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 03: U.S. District Court judge David O. Carter asks a skid row resident how long the water dispensers have been out of water while touring the area on Friday, April 3, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. LAPD officer Deon Joseph, who was escorting the judge, said he noticed the water dispenser empty about 1 1/2 weeks ago. Carter is the judge at the center of the Orange County riverbed homeless case. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County reaches 'very sad milestone' as coronavirus deaths rise
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Patrick McGreevy
item.description: In the last week, deaths have roughly doubled and now stand at more than 570, the county's health director says.
item.content:encoded: In the last week, deaths have roughly doubled and now stand at more than 570, the county's health director says.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: UC dropped the SAT and ACT amid coronavirus. Here's why some want them back next year
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UC dropped the SAT and ACT requirements for admission next fall amid coronavirus closures, but faculty voted to keep them for at least more five years.
item.content:encoded: UC dropped the SAT and ACT requirements for admission next fall amid coronavirus closures, but faculty voted to keep them for at least more five years.

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK - JUNE 27: SAT test preparation books sit on a shelf at a Barnes and Noble store June 27, 2002 in New York City. College Board trustees decided June 27 to add a written essay and other changes to the SAT in an overhaul of the college entrance exam. The first administration of the new SAT will occur in March of 2005. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

item.title: Gang intervention workers helping keep residents indoors, safe during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Nicole Santa Cruz, Photography by Genaro Molina
item.description: In Los Angeles, gang intervention workers are an essential workforce, helping to keep the peace and now educating communities about the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: In Los Angeles, gang intervention workers are an essential workforce, helping to keep the peace and now educating communities about the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 11, 2020 - Gernay Quinnie, 38, left, with Reclaiming America's Communities through Empowerment (R.A.C.E.) helps feed the homeless who live in a vacant parking lot in South Los Angeles on April 11, 2020. Possibly 50 people live homeless at the site. Quinnie and fellow workers with R.A.C.E. also give the homeless hygiene bags which includes, toiletries, hand sanitizers, masks and gloves to help protect them during the coronavirus pandemic. Quinnie, with the South LA-based gang intervention organization, is also risking his own health: he suffers from an immune disorder. "If i don't go out, who else is going to do it," he said. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 27,525 pounds of carrots a day: How L.A. schools are feeding the masses
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Coronavirus: While food banks struggle, L.A.'s schools are feeding the hungry
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: While food banks struggle, L.A.'s schools are feeding the hungry

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 01, 2020 LAUSD school board member Jackie Goldberg, at 75 years of age thanks workers distributing food as she is visiting South East High School in South Gate Wednesday morning April 1, 2020 as she is driving around from school to school in Southeast L.A. County to see how things are going. The campuses are closed because of the coronavirus Covid 19, but 63 schools are being used to hand out computers. In addition, students are picking up computers and internet hotspots from schools as well as homework packets. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Monica City Manager Rick Cole resigns, citing divisions over coronavirus budget cuts

item.title: Some cities are blocking California efforts to protect homeless people from coronavirus, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California's effort to move homeless people into hotels to blunt the coronavirus spread has helped, but advocates say it's hampered by local opposition.
item.content:encoded: California's effort to move homeless people into hotels to blunt the coronavirus spread has helped, but advocates say it's hampered by local opposition.

item.title: Volunteer killed at food drive in Sylmar after he was pinned between two vehicles
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: The San Fernando man was loading food into a car trunk when the driver of a Ford Expedition SUV suddenly drove forward and crushed him against the car.
item.content:encoded: The San Fernando man was loading food into a car trunk when the driver of a Ford Expedition SUV suddenly drove forward and crushed him against the car.

item.title: L.A. races to save 15,000 homeless people from coronavirus — one hotel room at a time

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: L.A. launches new effort to move 15,000 people out of overcrowded shelters and encampments and into hotel rooms.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 06: Omar Spry of Los Angeles Housing Community Investment Department, pushes a cart of residents' bags into a West L.A. hotel that has been turned into housing for the homeless during the coronavirus pandemic. The homeless housing is through a program with the Hotel Assn. of Los Angeles, Los Angeles County, city of Los Angeles and non-profits. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: Customers boycott a pharmacy. People scream at a family on the street. A church faces police "shaming." The common thread linking all these stories

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO CA - FEBRUARY 29: Hundreds of Chinatown residents along with local and state officials take to the streets protest against racism against the Chinese community during a march down Grant Avenue from Chinatown's Portsmouth Square to Union Square in San Francisco, Calif. Saturday, February 29, 2020. Racism against the Chinese community has increased since the discovery of the first coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan, China has spread globally. (Jessica Christian/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images)
media:content.media:credit: San Francisco Chronicle/Hearst N/Hearst Newspapers via Getty Imag

item.title: As coronavirus rages, a Vietnamese diva falls silent. But her legend lives on
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: Thai Thanh, who reigned over Vietnamese American popular music for nearly six decades, died in March. Her legions of fans have mourned from home.
item.content:encoded: Thai Thanh, who reigned over Vietnamese American popular music for nearly six decades, died in March. Her legions of fans have mourned from home.

media:content.media:description: Viet Le holds a portrait of his beloved mother, the iconic Thai Thanh, following a private funeral procession for the singer in Westminster. (Nguoi Viet Daily News)
media:content.media:credit: (Nguoi Viet Daily News)/(Nguoi Viet Daily News)

item.title: Coronavirus rules challenge Holocaust memorial tradition, but it survives
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: Holocaust remembrances have been upended this year by a new enemy: COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Holocaust remembrances have been upended this year by a new enemy: COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: Undated handout photo of Edith Frankie in front of the Tree of Testimony at Los Angeles Museum of the Holocaust.The Tree of Testimony is a 70-screen video sculpture comprised of nearly 51,000 video testimonies of Holocaust survivors over the course of a single year. (John Pregulman / Museum of the Holocaust)
media:content.media:credit: John Pregulman/John Pregulman /Museum of the Holocaust

item.title: Coronavirus Zoom wedding ditches the plan and lets loose needed joy
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic forced Owen Smigelski and Carolyne Johnson to scrap plans for a big wedding, but they got married anyway on Zoom.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus pandemic forced Owen Smigelski and Carolyne Johnson to scrap plans for a big wedding, but they got married anyway on Zoom.

media:content.media:description: With Ian, 9, in background, Owen Smigelski and Carolyne Johnson talk to their guests before cutting the wedding cake. The two were married Saturday, April 11, 2020 and because of the coronavirus pandemic, they perform the wedding over zoom.

item.title: Boom times for cannabis businesses as Californians, in a pandemic fog, isolate indoors
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Carolyn Cole
item.description: In the north state, the weed industry is thriving — apparently because so many customers are sheltering in place, in need of THC therapy.
item.content:encoded: In the north state, the weed industry is thriving — apparently because so many customers are sheltering in place, in need of THC therapy.

media:content.media:description: RED BLUFF, CA - APRIL 16: Brian Phillips, age 60, has been self-medicating with pot since he was a boy when he got in a car accident and his mother gave him some to ease his pain. He moved from Los Angele to Red Bluff, California in 1972, where he rides around town in an electric wheelchair after suffering a second accident later in life. There are no medical marijuana dispensaries within miles, but Phillips has no problem finding pot. "There ain't no dispensaries in this town," said Phillips, "This is one poor town." He worries that there are sick people in his apartment building, but so far there has only been one case of Covid-19 in Red Bluff, CA. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Living in an airport shuttle, a musician's coronavirus lament: 'I don't know how I am going to survive this'
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: Mariachis play love songs at wedding receptions, songs about Mexico at festivals; they sing birthday songs and morning serenades. They subsist on joy, but they also experience sadness. Then came the novel coronavirus, which choked off almost every source of revenue.
item.content:encoded: Mariachis play love songs at wedding receptions, songs about Mexico at festivals; they sing birthday songs and morning serenades. They subsist on joy, but they also experience sadness. Then came the novel coronavirus, which choked off almost every source of revenue.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 2020: With socks hanging to dry overhead, from left, Eduardo Santizo, 75, Pedro Zamoya, 68, and Arturo Ramos, 51, gathered inside a shuttle bus parked at Mariachi Plaza on a cold Wednesday night and sang a mariachi song after Zamoya shared half a chicken and mango with his friends, as all three have been unable to find work for three weeks, in Los Angeles, Calif., on April 8, 2020. Pedro Zamoya, 68, began living out of an airport shuttle bus three days ago after he couldn't pay his $650 monthly rent. The trumpeter said his landlord wanted rent despite a moratorium on evictions due to the coronavirus pandemic, Zamoya said he didn't want any problems and moved out. He borrowed $250 from his son to live in the shuttle. He doesn't know if he'll have a place to stay next month. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Magnitude 3.2 quake shakes near Valle Vista, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.2 earthquake was reported Friday evening one mile from Valle Vista, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: State-funded L.A. 'surge hospital' opens at St. Vincent Medical Center
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Los Angeles' "surge" hospital opened this week on the site of the shuttered St. Vincent Medical Center and began taking COVID-19 patients.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles' "surge" hospital opened this week on the site of the shuttered St. Vincent Medical Center and began taking COVID-19 patients.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 13: St. Vincent Medical Center located at 2131 West 3rd st. in Los Angeles is back in business to help ease the pressure on local hospitals amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. Staff set up beds and other equipment ready to receive patients with Covid-19 starting Monday. The 266-bed facility will serve as a hospital accepting patients that have tested positive at a different regional hospital that may be at capacity. Los Angeles on Monday, April 13, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California opens highway rest stops to food trucks, helping truckers get warm meals
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Food trucks will be allowed to operate at the 86 state rest areas in California during the COVID-19 pandemic to provide access to food for highway motorists, including truck drivers, as well as economic relief to food truck operators, Caltrans announced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Food trucks will be allowed to operate at the 86 state rest areas in California during the COVID-19 pandemic to provide access to food for highway motorists, including truck drivers, as well as economic relief to food truck operators, Caltrans announced Friday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA JULY 19, 2017-Trucks make there way up the Gerald Desmond Bridge at the Port of Los Angeles Wednesday. The nation's largest port complex will seek up to $14 billion in public and private funds to slash air pollution and health risks to Southern Californians by replacing diesel trucks and cargo-handling equipment with zero-emmissions technology over the next two decades. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Judge: Rick Singer's notes raise 'disturbing' questions about the case against his college admissions clients
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A judge wrote Friday that Rick Singer's notes raise "serious and disturbing" questions about the investigation into his college admissions scam.
item.content:encoded: A judge wrote Friday that Rick Singer's notes raise "serious and disturbing" questions about the investigation into his college admissions scam.

media:content.media:description: BOSTON, MA - MARCH 12: William "Rick" Singer leaves Boston Federal Court after being charged with racketeering conspiracy, money laundering conspiracy, conspiracy to defraud the United States, and obstruction of justice on March 12, 2019 in Boston, Massachusetts. Singer is among several charged in alleged college admissions scam. (Photo by Scott Eisen/Getty Images) ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, CM - OUTS * NM, PH, VA if sourced by CT, LA or MoD ** ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, CM - OUTS * NM, PH, VA if sourced by CT, LA or MoD **

item.title: Coronavirus infections could be much more widespread than believed, California study suggests
item.dc:creator: Melanie Mason, Deborah Netburn
item.description: A new study by Stanford University, using antibody blood tests, estimates that the number of cases in Santa Clara County may be 50 to 85 times greater than what was previously known.
item.content:encoded: A new study by Stanford University, using antibody blood tests, estimates that the number of cases in Santa Clara County may be 50 to 85 times greater than what was previously known.

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 2020: Healthcare workers tend to a driver in line at a drive-through Coronavirus (COVID-19) testing site at the Westminster Mall in Westminster, CA, Wednesday, April 8, 2020. The site is run by Elevated Health and is doing nasal testing for $125 and antibody testing for $75. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Ventura County faith leaders demand officials allow socially distant gatherings amid coronavirus shutdown
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: The clergymen "wish to exercise their religious freedom in a manner that respects the current social distancing restrictions and the health and safety of the community," according to the demand letter.
item.content:encoded: The clergymen "wish to exercise their religious freedom in a manner that respects the current social distancing restrictions and the health and safety of the community," according to the demand letter.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: People gather in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

(AP Photo/Paul Sakuma)

Chavez Blvd. and Soto St. has slow down as California officials extended stay-at-home orders into May and residents entered Easter weekend with unprecedented limits on their movements. Most of the people are adhering to the orders by mayor to wear masks while out running errands. Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: MEXICALI, MEX-MARCH 8, 2020: Emmanuel Samano Arrreola, fourth right, leads a drumming performance at La Chinesca alley on March 8, 2020, in Mexicali, Mexico. The city has coined their Chinatown, La Chinesca and has a large Chinese influence with the Chinese restaurants on many blocks. (Photo By Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Hospitals across California have been slow to reveal COVID-19 cases among medical staff, data that they are not required to disclose and that the state does not comprehensively track.

item.title: Coronavirus is no match for 8-year-old's birthday party
item.dc:creator: Al Seib
item.description: Parade, games presents coronavirus can't stop birthday party
item.content:encoded: Parade, games presents coronavirus can't stop birthday party

media:content.media:description: THOUSAND OAKS, CA - APRIL 16: Peyton Buss waits for cars full of fellow team members from his 2019 Conejo Valley Little League All Star Baseball Team to drive by his home in Thousand Oaks to celebrate his 8th birthday amid the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic. Peyton's parents, Jill and Daniel Buss with the help of friends organized a "drive-by birthday party" with family and his best friends. Over 25 vehicles filled with cheering parents and children drove around his cul de sac in front of the Buss home several times bestowing Peyton with balloons, gifts, cards and placards. "This is the best birthday party I've ever had !" exclaimed Peyton. "People need social interaction," said his Mother Jill, "this is a new norm so we have to make due." Thousand Oaks on Thursday, April 16, 2020 in Thousand Oaks, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County suffers a disproportionate share of coronavirus deaths amid a grim week
item.dc:creator: Sean Greene, Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money, Priscella Vega
item.description: Coronavirus: L.A. County -- and the Southern California region -- seeing an outsized number of deaths
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: L.A. County -- and the Southern California region -- seeing an outsized number of deaths

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 14: A man talks with a healthcare worker outside Kedren Community Health Center during the coronavirus pandemic on Tuesday, April 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, {state. Kedren Community Health Center is offering walk-up coronavirus testing along with other medical services in South Los Angeles. ({photographer} / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: An ex-con teaches other former convicts how to live life outside prison walls
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: 'Big John' has advice for other ex-cons. 'Have I been to jail? Yes. But I keep those things behind me.'
item.content:encoded: 'Big John' has advice for other ex-cons. 'Have I been to jail? Yes. But I keep those things behind me.'

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - DEC. 19, 2019. Big John leads a weekly meeting of the group Second Call in the basement of the Abundant Life Christian Church in Los Angeles on Thursday night, Dec. 19, 2019. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Southern California mountain lions get temporary endangered species status
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: The state Fish and Game Commission on Thursday set the stage for a fierce environmental battle by granting temporary endangered species status to the several hundred cougars still roaming Southern California and the Central Coast.
item.content:encoded: The state Fish and Game Commission on Thursday set the stage for a fierce environmental battle by granting temporary endangered species status to the several hundred cougars still roaming Southern California and the Central Coast.

media:content.media:description: A remote camera captured the mountain lion known as P-41.

item.title: Coronavirus crisis could trigger huge California deficits, lawmakers are told
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Legislative Analyst Gabriel Petek told members of the state Senate's budget committee to prepare for a projected deficit of as much as $35 billion in the near future.
item.content:encoded: Legislative Analyst Gabriel Petek told members of the state Senate's budget committee to prepare for a projected deficit of as much as $35 billion in the near future.

media:content.media:description: State Senators Jim Nielson, R-Gerber, left, and Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, top right, members of the Senate budget committee sit six feet apart, as they view a large video screen, left, during a hearing of the special subcommittee on COVID-19, at the Capitol in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, April 16, 2020. Lawmakers are looking into how Gov. Gavin Newsom has been spending money to address the new coronavirus crisis. Due to the unusual circumstances only Nielsen, vice chair of the committee and Mitchell, chair of the committee, attended the hearing in person while other committee members, those testifying and the public joined by video. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: California Times folds Burbank Leader, Glendale News-Press and La Cañada Valley Sun
item.dc:creator: Meg James
item.description: L.A. Times' parent company will close three Times Community Newspaper publications and lay off 14 as it makes budget cuts during coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Times' parent company will close three Times Community Newspaper publications and lay off 14 as it makes budget cuts during coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: EL SEGUNDO,CA --THURSDAY, JUNE 28, 2018--The new sign on top of the new Los Angeles Times headquarters in El Segundo, CA., June 28, 2018. The paper, recently bought by, Soon-Shiong, is leaving its downtown L.A. headquarters for the El Segundo building, owned by Soon-Shiong, after previous owner, Chicago-based Tribune Media Co., sold the downtown property to Canadian developer Onni Group in 2016. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Two house fires in Los Angeles County leave three people dead
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: A Pomona house fire killed one teenage girl and sent another to the hospital in grave condition. Earlier Thursday, a Walnut house fire killed two people.
item.content:encoded: A Pomona house fire killed one teenage girl and sent another to the hospital in grave condition. Earlier Thursday, a Walnut house fire killed two people.

media:content.media:description: A house fire in Pomona killed one child and left another in grave condition. An adult female relative suffered minor injuries.

item.title: O.C. sheriff reports an uptick in domestic violence calls amid coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Domestic violence calls have increased 25% when compared with the same period in March and April last year, said Sheriff Don Barnes.
item.content:encoded: Domestic violence calls have increased 25% when compared with the same period in March and April last year, said Sheriff Don Barnes.

media:content.media:description: The scene outside the Central Men's Jail in Santa Ana.

item.title: Among the 'climate monsters' that afflict California, Megadrought is the most reliable
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: A new study says a megadrought rivaling anything known in prehistory may be developing in the American West.
item.content:encoded: A new study says a megadrought rivaling anything known in prehistory may be developing in the American West.

media:content.media:description: The weather monsters that afflict California sound like they came from B movies.

item.title: Irene Hirano Inouye, champion of Japanese American causes, dies at 71
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Irene Hirano Inouye, a prodigious fundraiser who led the nation's premier Japanese American museum in Los Angeles and built bridges across cultures and countries, has died.
item.content:encoded: Irene Hirano Inouye, a prodigious fundraiser who led the nation's premier Japanese American museum in Los Angeles and built bridges across cultures and countries, has died.

media:content.media:description: President Barack Obama talks with Irene Hirano, widow of Hawaii Sen. Daniel Inouye, in the East Room of the White House in Washington, Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2013, where he awarded Inouye with the Presidential Medal of Freedom. (AP Photo/ Evan Vucci)

item.title: California food workers will get extra paid sick leave amid coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Food sector companies in California that employ 500 or more workers will be required to offer two weeks of additional paid sick leave to workers during the coronavirus crisis under an executive order signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom.
item.content:encoded: Food sector companies in California that employ 500 or more workers will be required to offer two weeks of additional paid sick leave to workers during the coronavirus crisis under an executive order signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom.

media:content.media:description: MARINA DEL REY, CA - APRIL 05: Everardo Gonzalez scans groceries behind and new plexiglas barrier at a Ralphs grocery store in Marina ?Del Rey during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, April 5, 2020 in Marina Del Rey, CA. Ralphs has put up plexiglas barriers around their cashier stations at several locations in Los Angeles. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Dozens of homeless people relocated after skid row shelter reports six coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith, Melanie Mason
item.description: Union Rescue Mission in downtown Los Angeles was scrambling to relocate dozens of homeless people after the coronavirus infected six of its residents.
item.content:encoded: Union Rescue Mission in downtown Los Angeles was scrambling to relocate dozens of homeless people after the coronavirus infected six of its residents.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 07: Staff and volunteers practice social distancing as they line up for lunch at Union Rescue Mission on Tuesday, April 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Union Rescue Mission continues to offer and supply hot meals to some of the most vulnerable during the Coronavirus pandemic, those who are homeless. (Mariah Tauger / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UC reels under staggering coronavirus costs; 'the worst impacts ... all at once'
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The University of California was hit with $558 million in unanticipated costs in March alone due to the coronavirus, a staggering sum as students canceled housing and dining contracts, medical centers paused elective surgeries and costs to gear up online learning soared.
item.content:encoded: The University of California was hit with $558 million in unanticipated costs in March alone due to the coronavirus, a staggering sum as students canceled housing and dining contracts, medical centers paused elective surgeries and costs to gear up online learning soared.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MARCH 11, 2020: Student Shaya Naimi, 19, hangs out on the steps of Powell Library at UCLA where classes have moved to online only on Wednesday, March 11, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus poses added challenges for hospital patients who are deaf or hard of hearing
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: As hospitals cope with coronavirus cases, deaf and hard of hearing patients face greater barriers accessing accommodations that help them understand what doctors are saying.
item.content:encoded: As hospitals cope with coronavirus cases, deaf and hard of hearing patients face greater barriers accessing accommodations that help them understand what doctors are saying.

item.title: Riverside County reports four new deaths and 144 new cases, including a postal worker
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Riverside announced four new deaths because of the coronavirus, but said the rate of increase is slower than expected, possibly because of social distancing.
item.content:encoded: Riverside announced four new deaths because of the coronavirus, but said the rate of increase is slower than expected, possibly because of social distancing.

media:content.media:description: MONTCLAIR, CA - APRIL 14: A public health care worker collects a nasal swab for novel coronavirus testing at a drive-through sample collection event held by San Bernardino County Department of Public Health at Montclair Plaza, Montclair, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here is the latest list of Orange County communities with coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: As the coronavirus pandemic widens in Orange County, here is the latest community-by-community breakdown.
item.content:encoded: As the coronavirus pandemic widens in Orange County, here is the latest community-by-community breakdown.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 2020: Street-side seating that is usually crowded with spring breakers and visitors sits empty as a man walks past the Longboard Restaurant & Pub that allows to go orders only until further notice, amid coronavirus pandemic restrictions downtown Huntington Beach, Calif., on March 18, 2020. Orange County bars, breweries and wineries were ordered to close, restaurants were told to offer take-out or delivery only, and people were told not to gather to curb transmission of the coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak at Lompoc prison is the worst in the nation: 69 inmates, 25 staff infected
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The nation's worst coronavirus outbreak in a prison is at the federal penitentiary in Lompoc, where 69 inmates and 25 staff members are infected.
item.content:encoded: The nation's worst coronavirus outbreak in a prison is at the federal penitentiary in Lompoc, where 69 inmates and 25 staff members are infected.

media:content.media:description: The Federal Correctional Institution in Lompoc, Calif., is shown in a Dec. 1995 photo. The prison, which houses low to medium security inmates, is on the same grounds as the Lompoc Federal Prison Camp, where former Gov., Fife Symington would likely serve his sentence. Symington resigned in disgrace Sept. 3, 1997, after a federal jury convicted him of defrauding lenders during his former career as a real estate developer. ( AP Photo/Santa Maria Times, Jeffrey May)

item.title: California stories from the pandemic
item.description: Los Angeles Times reporter Susanne Rust and photographer Carolyn Cole are embarking on a road journey throughout California. They aim to give voice to those in remote parts of California as they grapple with the worst health and economic calamity of our lifetimes.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Times reporter Susanne Rust and photographer Carolyn Cole are embarking on a road journey throughout California. They aim to give voice to those in remote parts of California as they grapple with the worst health and economic calamity of our lifetimes.

media:content.media:description: MADERA, CA - APRIL 09: "El Masqarillo" means the mask in Spanish. It's the name of Ramon Larios's horse, which has a white face. Ramon Larios works as a farmer growing pastacios in Madera County, California. He says his business hasn't been effected at all by the coronavirus and that jobs are plentiful in Madera County. His horse "El Masqarillo," was abused before he got him two years ago, but is much better now. They go for rides together in the afternoon and he wears his scarf for the cold while he rides, not to combat germs. A look at rural California during the time of coronavirus Covid 19. Madera County on Thursday, April 9, 2020 in Madera, CA. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Global warming is making western U.S. 'megadrought' the worst in centuries, study says
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: A two-decade-long dry spell that has parched much of the western United States is turning into one of the deepest 'megadroughts' of the past 1,200 years.
item.content:encoded: A two-decade-long dry spell that has parched much of the western United States is turning into one of the deepest 'megadroughts' of the past 1,200 years.

media:content.media:description: This photo from 2013 shows a bathtub ring marking the high-water line along Black Canyon on Lake Mead. A two-decade-long dry spell is turning into one of the deepest megadroughts in the western United States in more than 1,200 years.
